title: The influence of repeated sprinting on the kinematics of butterfly swimming.

<record><header><identifier>
oai:www.e-space.mmu.ac.uk:2173/93360</identifier><datestamp>2010-03-02T11:14:43Z</datestamp><setSpec>hdl_2173_808</setSpec><setSpec>hdl_2173_85256</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/ http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd" ><dc:title>The influence of repeated sprinting on the kinematics of butterfly swimming.</dc:title><dc:creator>Osborough, Conor D.</dc:creator><dc:creator>Payton, Carl J.</dc:creator><dc:subject>Repeated sprinting</dc:subject><dc:subject>Kinematics</dc:subject><dc:subject>Butterfly swimming</dc:subject><dc:description>The purpose of this study was to determine the effect of
repeated sprint performance and fatigue on the kinematics of
butterfly swimming. Six experienced national youth male butterfly
swimmers undertook a maximal effort repeated sprint
test set, during which swimmers were filmed with two underwater
and two above water cameras (oblique plane) at 50Hz.
The whole body was digitised during a full stroke cycle for each
view, with the three-dimensional coordinates being obtained
using a DLT algorithm. The results of this study indicate that
as swimming speed decreased (i) stroke rate decreased while stroke length remained relatively constant, (ii) hand movement
patterns remained similar while changes in elbow angle suggested
that the effectiveness of joint flexors and extensors may
have been reduced, (iii) the Upsweep, Recovery and Catch
appear to the critical stroke phases when swimmers become
fatigued.</dc:description><dc:description>Full text of this article is available at http://www.fade.up.pt/rpcd/_arquivo/RPCD_vol.6_supl.2.pdf</dc:description><dc:publisher>Revista Portuguesa de Ciencias do Desporto</dc:publisher><dc:date>2010-03-02T11:14:43Z</dc:date><dc:type>Article</dc:type><dc:identifier>Portuguese journal of sports sciences, 2006, vol. 6, no. suppl 2, pp. 70-73</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>1645-0523</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>http://hdl.handle.net/2173/93360</dc:identifier><dc:language>en</dc:language><dc:relation>http://www.fade.up.pt/rpcd/entrada_ingles.html</dc:relation><dc:relation>http://www.fade.up.pt/rpcd/_arquivo/RPCD_vol.6_supl.2.pdf</dc:relation></oai_dc:dc></metadata></record>
